title: The Poison of Unforgiveness
devotional:
Old Mr. Abernathy was known for two things: his prize-winning roses and his unforgiving spirit. His garden was a vibrant tapestry of color and fragrance, a testament to his dedication and skill. Yet, behind the meticulously manicured hedges lived a man consumed by bitterness. Years ago, his business partner, a close friend, had betrayed him, leading to financial ruin. Mr. Abernathy had never forgiven him. The anger festered, poisoning his relationships and casting a shadow over his life.

One sweltering summer afternoon, a young woman named Sarah, new to the neighborhood, accidentally backed her car into Mr. Abernathy’s prized rose trellis, crushing several of his beloved blooms. Mortified, she rushed to his door, tears in her eyes, ready to face his wrath. To her surprise, Mr. Abernathy didn't explode. He looked at the damage, then at Sarah's distraught face, and sighed. A flicker of something akin to understanding crossed his features. He simply said, "Accidents happen."

Sarah, emboldened by his unexpected calmness, offered to pay for the damages and help him rebuild the trellis. Over the next few weeks, as they worked side-by-side, a strange thing happened. Mr. Abernathy began to soften. Sarah’s genuine remorse and willingness to make amends chipped away at the wall he had built around his heart. He started sharing stories about his roses, about his life before the betrayal, about the dreams he had once held.

One evening, as they stood admiring the newly restored trellis, Mr. Abernathy turned to Sarah and said, "You know, I’ve been holding onto anger for so long, it's like a poison. Seeing your willingness to fix what you broke… it’s made me realize I need to do some fixing of my own." He paused, his voice thick with emotion. "I think… I think it’s time I finally forgive my old friend." 

Mr. Abernathy's story reminds us that forgiveness is not just a gift we give to others; it's a gift we give to ourselves. Holding onto resentment and bitterness only serves to imprison us in the past, preventing us from experiencing the fullness of life that God intends for us. Forgiveness, though often difficult, is the key that unlocks the door to healing and freedom.
image_description: A damaged rose trellis with several crushed roses, bathed in the soft light of late afternoon.
insights: Jesus' teachings on forgiveness are central to the Christian faith. In the Lord's Prayer, we ask God to 'forgive us our debts, as we also have forgiven our debtors' (Matthew 6:12). This highlights the reciprocal nature of forgiveness. We cannot expect to receive God's forgiveness if we are unwilling to extend it to others. Furthermore, Jesus emphasizes the importance of unlimited forgiveness, urging us to forgive 'seventy times seven' (Matthew 18:22), a symbolic expression of boundless grace.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I confess that I often struggle to forgive those who have wronged me. The pain and resentment linger, poisoning my heart and mind. I ask for Your grace to release the bitterness and embrace the freedom that comes with forgiveness. Help me to see others through Your eyes, with compassion and understanding. Give me the strength to extend forgiveness, just as You have forgiven me. In Jesus' name, I pray. Amen.
reflection: Who is someone you need to forgive? What steps can you take today to begin the process of forgiveness? How might releasing the burden of resentment free you to experience greater joy and peace?
